results.title: Bad Street Brawler for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual and blurb card in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Bad Street Brawler, the player plays the character Duke Davis, a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist. Duke has to work his way through each level beating up the crooks that get in his way. Before the start of the next stage, quotes are introduced to entertain the player, such as “Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you”. The player’s moves are limited to kicks and punches but new moves and attacks become available as the game progresses, along with new enemy types such as gorillas flinging bananas, menacing stakeboarders and circus strongmen. Bad Street Brawler is one of two games designed specifically for Mattel’s Power Glove.

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy is a sports game based on Australian Rules Football. The game is played from a third-person perspective, where the player has the ability to perform the basic actions of the footy player currently in posession of the ball. A player can pick one of eighteen Australian football teams to compete against the computer, or against another player on the same system. The game includes a Kick to Kick Training Session, a Single Game mode and a Season mode where one, four or six players can play multiple games that culminate in the Grand Final.

A player wins by having the most points at the end of the game. Points are added by either kicking a goal (six points) or a behind (one point). To move the football, a player with the ball can either kick or handball the ball, and a player without the ball can either mark the ball or tackle an opposition player with the ball. The game was only released in Australia.

results.title: Exterior wall with tyrolean finish
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
This first coat consists of a water repellent cement. Materials and their proportions are stated. The surface is scratched to provide a key for the next coat. This second coat is applied with the help of dots and screeds to ensure a true vertical surface. The formation of a plinth is demonstrated. This is made in two stages, core and finishing coat. The wall itself may be finished in various ways. Three different kinds of finishing coats are shows: Tyrolean finish, pebble dash, and rough cast.

results.title: Cornice mould and fibrous plaster cast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
The architect’s drawing, paper template, zinc template, stock and horse - these are the stages that produce the tool that the plasterer will use. The stages of forming the mould are demonstrated in detail, the core and the final coat without muffle.

results.title: Ceiling with scrapite finish
results.creator_credit: Topical Film Company and Brent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plastering”.
One of a series of four films which gives a basic training in plastering as applied to building construction. The use of expanded metal lathing is demonstrated and the way in which the plaster adheres to it. Three coats are applied, render, float and set. The making of dots and screeds is shown. Before the final coat is applied the cornice is run. The method of cutting the mould for this and the addition of horse and handle is shown. Screeds and running rule are fitted in position and the cornice is run. Finally, the finishing coat is applied to the ceiling.

Before the final coat is applied the cornice is run. The method of cutting the mould for this and the addition of horse and handle is shown. results.title: Plant Supervisors Problems

results.title: The Trouble with women
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Historically interesting film - to be taken in context to the year it was produced, ie the 1950’s! A supervisor, Brad, discusses his objections to a new woman worker with the Personnel Manager. He recalls trouble with previous women employees: one kept her desk like a dressing table and objected to moving to a different one; another engaged girl gave insufficient notice of leaving to marry; then there was absenteeism. The Personnel Manager suggests that it is up to Brad whether the new “girl” adds up to trouble. The audience is asked: “What is Brad’s trouble?” Useful for feminist theory studies.

results.title: The Personal problem
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Shows that a supervisor who avoids discussing an employee’s personal problem with him may cause a production fall-off by the worker.

results.title: The Hidden grievance
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Plant Supervisors Problems”.
Part of a six film series dramatising case problems met within industry. This film helps to make supervisors aware of the need for sensitivity in recognising and understanding underlying causes of an employee grievance in order to handle it satisfactorily.
